column4: I'm trying to install ubuntuon a neighbour's desktop machine. windows is v. slow on it.  it has 3 boot options: hdd, fdd, cd.  whatcan I do? the .iso for 12.10 is bigger than a CD
is that the last release of ubuntu that will support old computers?  do you have an alt distro you know of that still loads on old machines please?
no. but it's a LTS which is (imho) a good idea for newbies to ubuntu
and as a bonus it should fit on a CD :)  also: if you install 12.04 you can immediately upgrade to 12.10 if you wish, but I wouldn't
thanks for your help.  what do you wuggest for burning .iso to CD?
on which OS? if windows: imgburn
then whatever ubuntu uses for burning CDs. no clue myself
do you know what hardware your neighbour has? lubuntu or xubuntu might be a very good idea
it will get faster over time usually
only if it's very old, but then yes
possible, especially for a OEM PC
ssh is the client, not the serevr
pastebin the full command you wrote and its output in a pastebin
